talk about the three bones of this
shoulder girdle and then the three
joints of the shoulder girdle so let's
get right into it what are the three
bones of the shoulder girdle I'm glad
you asked the first one is the clavicle
and then we have the scapula and lastly
the proximal end of the humerus so the
proximal humerus and if I were to look
in this picture over here we can see
those bones the first one is the
clavicle this is also called the
collarbone and then we have on the
posterior and we have the scapula and
then we have this bone which is the
humerus but for the shoulder girdle
we're just talking about the proximal
humerus so the proximal end of the
humerus so if I were to draw something
around it we're talking about pretty
much this structure here forgive my
terrible drawing but you get the point
that is what we are referring to with
the shoulder girdle the clavicle the
scapula and the proximal humerus so now
let's talk about the three joints and
these are the three points of
articulation where one bone connects
with the next so let's talk about the
first one which is the sternal
clavicular joint now just by the name of
this joint you should be able to
determine what it connects to what and
that is the joint the connection between
the sternum and the clavicle so here we
have the sternum but specifically this
top portion of the start sternum we call
the manubrium so we have the manubrium
and that connects with the clavicle and
that joint right here is the
sternoclavicular joint you can see it
also in this picture in a little more
detail here is
clavicle and this is the manubrium of
the sternum
that is the sternal clavicular joint now
that joint it's very significant because
this is the one point of articulation
that connects the upper extremities so
we're dealing with the entire arm that's
the one point where we have the upper
extremities connecting to the trunk okay
so that's sternoclavicular joint very
significant there that's the one point
of bone to bone connection between the
upper extremities and the trunk and that
is between the clavicle and the
manubrium of the sternum we have a
number of ligaments involve that we're
not going to talk about in this video
but we are going to talk about in later
videos so that's the first joint the
sternoclavicular joint let's move on to
the second which is the
acromioclavicular joint and that is the
joint where the clavicle
once again is articulating with a
structure on the scapula and that
structure is called the acromion process
so right here acromion process which is
this soup superior elevation of the
scapula so we have this projection
that's coming out in the superior aspect
of the scapula and that is called the
acromion process which then makes sense
for us to call it the acromioclavicular
joint so let me just draw an arrow right
here acromioclavicular joint which is
the second joint you can see that also
here they are chromium and the clavicle
forming the acromioclavicular joint
let's then move on to the third and
final joint which is the glenohumeral
joint and that's where the head of the
humerus is articulating with the glenoid
fossa now if we look at the scapula once
again the glenoid fossa is the structure
that we have under here you can't see
because it's covered by a bunch of
ligament and the capsule and all that
jazz but because we have the Glenn
oyel fossa and the head of the humerus
the proximal humerus and the head right
here we call that the glenohumeral joint
you can see that once again here this
joint is the glenohumeral joint where
the head of the humerus is articulating
with the glenoid fossa of the scapula so
that's pretty much it let's do a quick
review quiz for these review quizzes
what you can do if you want to test

structures are so first the three bones
of the shoulder girdle would be number
one this bone and that is the clavicle
then we have this bone and that is the
scapula and then we have the proximal
humerus the clavicle the scapula and
proximal humerus and then in terms of
the joints we have three joints we have
the sternal clavicular joint we have the
acromioclavicular joint and then we have
the glenohumeral joint so those are the
